newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins fall on new freezing rumours.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins fall on new freezing rumours.

text.p: Prices of Russian MinFin bonds fell in nervous trading on Wednesday, with the market unsettled by rumours, denied by a finance ministry official, that some new bonds had been frozen, dealers said.
"These rumours should be checked out carefully, but such information is enough to drive the market down," an ICFI Moscow Partners bank dealer said.
But a finance ministry official who declined to be named told Reuters on Wednesday that no new bonds had been frozen.
"We do not have such information (about freezing new bonds), there is nothing new about this matter," he told Reuters.
An International Moscow bank dealer said "There are few bids on the market, just offers, with some banks not quoting at all."
Dealers said the market could also be nervous about the health of President Boris Yeltsin and the extent to which he is in control.
"Somebody may be affected by it, but the fall may be also due to a correction after (last week's) rise," one dealer said.
The presidential press service said earlier that Yeltsin, resting in north-western Russia, had signed two decrees today.
